bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 1, 1890

div1.p: Lazear is distressed by his mother's illness. He discusses London and his observations of surgical operations.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 1, 1890

opener.dateline:
2 Queen Square Place
London W.C.
Aug 1 1890

div1.p:
I received your letter
of July 21, this morning. I am
very distressed to hear that you have
been so sick. I hope you were
really as much better as you say
you were. This certainly must be
a terrible summer in America. I saw
by to-days London paper, that the thermometer in New York was 99° and
that there were many cases of prostration.
I hope you are now in Brownsville.
Even if you are back in Pittsburgh
you will have a more comfortable room
at uncle Tom's. I know I have been
writing very ridiculous letters lately
but I have to write them hurriedly
and I am nearly always tired.
This sight seeing business is very
good as an education but there is
very little pleasure in it. You cannot
help rushing. To see everything here right
would take a year.

On Wednesday morning I went to the
National Gallery but I did not have
time to go all over it, so I will have
to go again to-day to-morrow at half-
past one I went over to St. Thomas'
Hospital and watched operations
- there all afternoon. In the evening
I took a walk in the fashionable residence
part of town near Hyde Park. On Thursday
morning I went to the bank after letters
but found that they were not distributed
yet, so I had to go again this morning
and even then I could not get the
papers. There is a great deal of delay
about this system of getting letters
through bankers. After going to the
bank yesterday I went to Sir John Soame's
Museum in Lincoln's Inn Fields. Here
I saw two of Hogarth's series, the
“Election” and the “Rake's Progress”.
I had already seen the “Marriage a la Mode at the National Gallery.
In the afternoon Norris and I went
through the Museum of the Royal College
of Surgeons staying there four hours.
It is the first medical museum in
the world. In it is the skeleton of
O'Brian the famous Irish giant of the last
century. He was eight feet tall. There
are a great many dissections of normal
bodies, besides pathological specimens
abnormalities, monstrosities etc.
In the evening we went to the French
Exhibition where they have a Wild
East show representing an Arab
camp with fancy riding, fights, etc.
There was a Frenchman there who
-had four trained lions. It is hard
to imagine trained lions but it is
an actual fact that this man made
these lions do a member of tricks
such as see-sawing, making pyramids
and driving in a chariot. The grounds
at the Exhibition were beautifully
decorated and lighted.

This morning I went up a monument to
look at the city from above but it
was not very satisfactory an account
of the smoke. This afternoon I went
to the Zoological Gardens. They have
a magnificent collection of animals
there. Norris and Knapp are at the
Crystal Palace this evening, but as
I was tired I concluded to take
a night off. My time in London is
drawing to a close and I have many
things to see yet but I cannot do
everything. I will go over to Paris
on Tuesday or Wednesday.

A letter was forwarded from Edinburgh
containing Prof. McColloms card and
a letter from Uncle Tom. Prof. McColloms
must have thought it strange that
I did not call and I cannot write
and explain to him as I do not know
his regular address. I wish you
would tell Uncle Tom about it and
ask if he knows Prof. McCollom's
address.

I spent all this morning at the National
-Gallery, and I enjoyed it thoroughly
although it is very tiresome to go over
a large gallery. Immediately after lunch
I went to the old Guildhall. They have
there a museum containing various
articles dug up in London some of
them Roman, also some old signs and
just now a collection of paintings.
Afterwards I went to the Royal Academy
of Arts where the annual exhibition
is being held. There were a great
many fine paintings there including
three of Alma Tadema, however I did
not like these as well as the ones
Mr. Walters has. They are all new of
course, two of them are portraits.
Altogether I have seen a vast
number of pictures to-day, there were
2119 at the Academy and about as
many at the Nl National Gallery. I
would like to take more time and
look carefully at a great many
of them. I did go over the National
Gallery carefully and I had been
there before.

I hope you are taking good care
of yourself and that the weather is
not affecting l you unless it happens
to be good weather.
